proposals.reasoning: With no mission history, I want a low-drama, low-variance opening. Alice and Diana both played straightforward, transparent games previously and are generally less erratic in early missions, which makes their choices here more informative. Starting with two players who are already inclined to be methodical should give us a cleaner baseline read on the table without overcomplicating the very first quest.

votes.comment: I know I’m good, Diana is a reasonable low-drama partner, and this is a standard safe opener with no better-informed alternative yet.
I’d rather avoid repeating last game’s ‘safe anchor’ pattern and get info on someone like Eve or Charlie instead of pairing Alice with Diana again.
Two solid, low-drama players for an info-gathering first mission; good baseline without overcomplicating things.
I’m on the team so I know at least one good is included; early info with a simple 2-player mission is valuable even with some risk on Alice.
Early clean mission is fine; rejecting a reasonable low-info first team would be needlessly suspicious.

discussion.content: With no info yet, I’d like to keep it simple and low-risk: I’m fine with a team of two from among the quieter, more methodical players—something like me plus Diana or me plus Charlie to start building a trust base.

I’d rather not default to the same “safe anchors” as last game—if you’re on it, I’d actually like to see someone like Eve paired with you so we start getting info on players who tend to fly under the radar. Diana especially came off very leader-y last time, which can quietly shape the table a bit too much this early.

I’m inclined to start with a low-drama pair like Alice and Diana—both played pretty straightforwardly last game, and keeping Eve off the very first team gives us a cleaner baseline read. If that feels too conservative, I’m fine swapping me in for Diana, but I’d still avoid adding Eve this early.

I’m okay with a simple Alice + Diana first mission since it’s low-risk and gives us a clean starting read, but if people are worried about repeating patterns from last game, I’d also be fine with Alice + Charlie as an alternative.

I slightly prefer Alice + Charlie here—both read fairly neutral to me, and keeping me and Bob off the very first mission gives us a cleaner data point if it passes or fails. If that’s the team, I’m happy to approve and use the result to start narrowing things down.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1’s Alice–Diana core succeeded with no fails, so reusing that pair is the most conservative good-aligned choice. Between Bob and Charlie for the third slot, I’m leaning Charlie because he already selected a clean team as leader on Mission 1, which is a small positive signal. This lineup keeps the minimal-change structure that several players favored, prioritizing mission success now while still letting us later compare how Bob/Eve behave from outside if this mission is also clean.

votes.comment: Reusing the clean Alice–Diana core with Charlie (who picked the first successful team) is the most conservative good-leaning option for Mission 2.
I still prefer reusing the Alice–Diana core but adding me instead of Charlie to avoid over-rewarding a single clean pick and to get a different data point.
Reusing the clean Alice–Diana core with just one added slot is the safest, lowest-variance option for Mission 2.
Reusing the proven Alice–me core with only Charlie added is the most conservative, info-light change and aligns with my earlier stated preference for Charlie over Bob here.
I slightly preferred adding Bob for better info, but this keeps the clean Alice–Diana core and is a reasonable low-risk Mission 2 team to support.

discussion.content: I’m happy to reuse the Alice–Diana core from the first mission since it was clean, and I’d lean toward adding either Bob or Charlie next—slight preference for Charlie given he picked a successful team already.

I like keeping Alice–Diana for now, but I’d actually prefer adding me over Charlie so we’re not just rewarding the previous leader and we get a slightly different data point. If this one’s clean too, that gives us a stronger baseline to judge both Charlie and Eve from the outside.

I’d rather lean into the clean info we have and run Alice–Diana again with me as the third, so we’re building off a known-success core instead of immediately changing two seats at once. Bob volunteering here is fine, but I’d rather get one more datapoint with a minimal-change team first.

I’m good sticking with the Alice–me core, and between Charlie and Bob I slightly prefer Charlie here since he already chose a clean team, but I’d like to hear a bit more from Eve before we lock anything in.

I’m fine reusing the Alice–Diana core, but I’d actually rather add Bob than just auto-trusting Charlie off one clean pick—if this passes, we learn a lot more about how Charlie/Eve sit from the outside.

proposals.reasoning: Given we’re already 2–0 up with both previous missions clean and Alice and Diana on each, the table clearly sees them as the safest pair right now. While I was earlier hesitant to auto-lock the same combo, forcing in a new uncertainty here risks a reject chain or, worse, introducing a spy when we’re one success from the win. At this point, if Alice/Diana were secretly bad we’d be in trouble regardless, so the most logical, consensus-driven choice is to lean into the information we have and propose Alice + Diana to maximize the chance of securing Mission 3.

votes.comment: Both prior missions with this core were clean; at 2–0 up, reusing the most trusted pair maximizes win odds and avoids introducing new risk.
I’ve already said I’m wary of auto-locking the Alice/Diana pair; if we’re wrong there the game ends, so I’d rather not double down without testing outside that overlap.
We’re 2–0 with this exact pair having a clean record; at this point, sticking with the most proven combo is the safest way to close out the game.
I know I’m good, and with two clean missions including this pair plus both Bob and Eve pushing to break it up, Alice looks more likely good than not. This is the safest path to a quick win.
Sticking with my earlier concern: if this exact pair is wrong we instantly lose with no new info, so I’d rather not auto-lock Alice+Diana here.

discussion.content: Given the first two missions were clean and I was on both, I’d really like to see this team be two of {me, Diana, Charlie}. Personally I’d lean Alice + Diana here, but I’m also okay with Diana + Charlie if people prefer.

I’m a bit wary of just reusing the same overlap every time—if there is a hidden spy, it’s most likely in that Alice/Diana pair—so I’d actually prefer something like Charlie plus one of me or Eve to at least broaden the info we get.
Given we’re already 2–0 with Alice and Diana looking solid so far, I’d rather not introduce two fresh variables here—Alice + Diana or Diana + me both seem safer than pulling in Bob/Eve right now.

Given we’re already 2–0 with Alice and me on both, I’d rather not suddenly add two unknowns—Alice + Diana seems safest to lock in the win, with Diana + Charlie as a reasonable backup if people are nervous about repeating the exact pair.

I’m a little nervous about just auto-locking the Alice/Diana pair again—if we’re wrong there, we lose on the spot—so I’d rather see something like Charlie + Bob this time to both stay relatively safe and actually learn something new.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning pretty hard toward Charlie as Merlin—he’s consistently steered picks to keep both of us off teams without sounding overtly accusatory, especially in Missions 2 and 3 where he keeps reinforcing the “clean core” and subtly resists adding me. Alice feels more open to adding either of us (she floated me on Mission 2 and was fine with Bob/Eve staying in the pool), and Diana’s caution reads more like generic risk-aversion than the targeted, quiet pressure Charlie kept applying against us.

I’m with you that Charlie is the best Merlin hit: he keeps pushing this “clean core” narrative in a way that systematically walls off me and you without ever having to call us suspicious directly, and he’s always got a neatly reasoned, low-drama rationale ready whenever adding either of us would be on the table. Alice feels more genuinely flexible about including us, and Diana’s tone reads more like a conservative good player trying not to throw away a lead than someone quietly shepherding the table.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Charlie consistently pushed the “clean core” of Alice and Diana while subtly resisting adding me or Eve, which is exactly how Merlin would try to keep known spies off teams without sounding accusatory. His arguments were always carefully framed as low-drama, information-focused reasoning rather than direct suspicion, matching a Merlin who knows who is evil but is trying not to reveal that knowledge.
